DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Margin Surgical Stapling Lung Lesion Present INd-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether a lesion or an observable abnormal structural change in the lung being found at the edge or border of an surgical incision closed by metal staples.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Surgical Margin Surgical Stapling Lung Lesion Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a lesion or an observable abnormal structural change in the lung being found at the edge or border of an surgical incision closed by metal staples.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: A technique of closing incisions and wounds, or of joining and connecting tissues, in which staples are used as sutures.:One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:Any observable abnormal structural change in a bodily part.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: A technique of closing incisions and wounds, or of joining and connecting tissues, in which staples are used as sutures.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.
Any observable abnormal structural change in a bodily part.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.
